Limited (4.5 20.9 lbs.) 1E-4 Bantam (21 55lbs.) 1E-5 Number of pedestrians exposed to aircraft flight operations () density of exposed population is the mean density of people per square o kilometer within the area of operation. The sAAT uses the average population density by square unit area for operations that cover areas with different population densities. Shelter factor ( shelter factor is the proportion of the population density that is exposed to the o vi
 sUAS operation. A shelter factor of one assumes a worst-case scenario where the population is entirely un-sheltered, conversely, a shelter factor of zero assumes the entirety of the population is sheltered. Probability of the failed aircraft being on a collision course with pedestrian ( is currently defined as where is the calculated horizontal distance from the o point of failure. Probability of the person not avoiding the collision ( currently assumes a unit of one due to the lack of data on what effect onboard o mitigations may provide in avoiding a ground collision with a third-party, or, the 
possibility of reactions by third-parties to avoid a potential collision threat. The value 
indicates the worst-case scenario with no effect from onboard mitigations, and no 
third-party reaction on the ground. Probability of collision with person resulting in a fatality ( is currently determined by the terminal KE of the aircraft, the impact angle, the o vii
 velocity equation, and the drag equation. Strengths and Weaknesses of the sAAT 3.2.1
Strengths of the sAAT model include: Consistency: Due to sAAT being a quantitative model, a given set of input parameters 
will consistently output the same answer providing repeatability.
Modular Architecture: Given the incipient environment of UAS data, the sAAT is built 
with the ability to change input data quickly should research provide an improved input 
parameter.
Building on Best Practices: The sAAT incorporates work validated by academia and 
industry. Weaknesses of the sAAT model include: Data Requirements Limit Features: sAAT is a relatively inflexible model unless further 
development is made to incorporate additional risks such as human error, aircraft 
penetration rates, effects of weather, impact severity, etc. Limited to Current Data: Being an inflexible model, accuracy of the sAAT is subject to 
accuracy of the underlying data. Due to a lack of published research; principal data such 
as aircraft reliability, minimum crash energies resulting in a fatality, and mission profiles 
are posited until conclusive studies or data are provided or collected. sAAT Ground-Risk Model Inputs3.2.2
The sAAT model allows the user to select standard mission profiles, aircraft characteristics, and 
selected computational variables, such as the level of energy determined to be fatal, for the risk 
analysis calculations. The basic input to the sAAT are the parameters defining the mission area 
and the aircraft characteristics. The aircraft and mission parameters are captured either in the 
form of general-purpose mission profiles, or as mission-specific values defined by the user. The 
required aircraft information includes gross-takeoff-weight, cross-sectional area of the aircraft, 
maximum aircraft speed, and maximum aircraft operating altitude. Additionally, the user enters 
the aircraft type, as either multirotor (e.g. a quadcopter), hybrid, or fixed-wing. Operational 
information includes the expected operating speed and altitude. The sAAT uses global maximum 
speed and altitude values if operation specific values are not otherwise specified as an input 
The required information for the designated mission area includes the size, shape, geographic 
location, and associated population densities for the region of operation. The region of operation 
is a set of geodetic latitude and longitude points provided by the user that define either the 
boundary of operation or the path of operation. Boundaries of operation can be a user defined 
circle, rectangle, or non-self-intersecting polygon. Paths of operation are a series of user-defined 
waypoints consisting of at least two points.
The density of the population within the route of flight is a significant operational risk factor 
within the mission profiles. Higher population density leads to a proportionally higher 
operational risk. The sAAT uses a pedestrian density model, which is based on LandScan viii
 Global Population Database developed by the U.S. Department of Energys Oak Ridge National 
Laboratory [11]. sAAT Ground-Risk Model Outputs3.2.3
The sAAT defines risk as the probability of fatality to a third-party. A third party is defined as a 
member of the public that is not a participant in the sUAS flight activity and is involuntarily 
exposed to an aircraft accident [12]. It is the bystander that happens to be near the planned area of 
operation of the sUAS. 
The sAAT model interface produces two outputs: (1) a graphical depiction of the risk value; and 
(2) the sensitivity analysis of risk factors. In combination, these three outputs can aid the analyst 
in determining if the risk assessment meets the acceptable safety levels. Additionally, the sAAT 
model provides the user with outputs that identify the probability of an impact to a third party, 
and the probability of the impact being fatal. The sensitivity analysis identifies the variables that 
had the most significant impact on driving the level of risk. 3-2. sAAT Input of Kinetic Energy and Probability of Fatality As illustrated in Figure 3-2, the input graph relates the PoF (%) to the estimated impact KE 
(Joules). The dark line that indicates 50% probability represents the upper threshold of acceptable 
risk. In this example, the PoF (risk) is 91.2% for an estimated KE at impact of 165.5 Joules. The 
graph indicates, in this notional example, that the computed risk level is above the 50% 
threshold.
The model identifies the parameters that have the highest sensitivity in driving the overall level 
of risk. This allows for the near real-time assessment of risk and helps support the determination 
of the acceptable risk level of sUAS operations. The sensitivity analysis output, as notionally 
shown in Figure 3-3, indicates which factors contribute the most to the risk. The risk factors and 
their associated rankings vary depending on the input data of the proposed sUAS operation. 
Factors are listed in rank order. Positive values on the right side of the y-axis contribute to higher 
risk. Negative values, measured towards the left of the y-axis contribute to reducing the risk. In ix
 this example, the risk can be reduced the most by reducing the greatest contributors: population 
density and the weight of the aircraft. NOTE: this is just a notional output to demonstrate the 
concept as shown in Figure 3-2. Flying faster would NOT reduce risk. 3-3. sAAT Output of Sensitivity Analysis sAAT Air-Risk Component3.2.4
Although sAAT does not currently include an air risk component, it is intended that an air risk 
component will be added, using the following Modified Endoh methodology [16].
The Air Risk model provides the localized risk analysis based on manned aircraft flight data, 
which is derived from MITREs Global Flight Informatics (MGFI) database of manned traffic 
under radar and surveillance coverage. It provides the probability of a Mid-Air Collision Risk, 
and has been successfully demonstrated with the FAA Pathfinder and UAS Test Site Programs, 
and the Navys Triton program.
Air risk occurs when an operator loses control of the sUAS, and the aircraft achieves unsafe 
proximity to an aircraft (an encounter). Once an encounter occurs, a calculation is made to 
determine the probability of a near mid-air collision, defined as the situation when the sUAS and 
a manned aircraft occupy the same 3-dimensional space.
Typically, the risk calculation will also include a measure of event severity. To calculate the 
severity component of an air risk, it is necessary to understand the conditional probability of 
fatality, given that a collision has occurred. However, research to determine this probability is not 
yet sufficient to determine the consequences of such a collision.
This methodology uses historical manned aircraft track data to determine a volumetric collision 
risk, that is, the probability of collision of an sUAS with a manned aircraft, moving in a volume 
of airspace defined by time of data, altitude, latitude, and longitude. It does not consider the 
characteristics of the sUAS. Necessary Simplifying Assumptions for sAAT 3.2.5
Calculating risk in a quantitative model requires data supporting all the above probabilities. 
When exact probabilities are not available, assumptions must be made about these values, so that 
the result may be calculated. x
 For example, the probability that the operator loses control of the aircraft, , is dependent on many factors, such as model, age, and weather. The sAAT model uses a mean time between failure derived from industry-wide operations as a value to represent the entirety of aircraft 
reliability [17]. Clearly there is a range of possible probabilities due to the variety of factors, but 
for purposes of computational simplicity, sAAT assumes a single point estimate for this 
parameter.
To speed computation (and development), probabilistic distributions are replaced by point 
estimates in the current version of sAAT.
Also, some risk components are ignored, as they are not easily quantified: Operator skill
Weather conditions during mission
Visual obstruction during Line of Sight Operations
Mechanical mitigations Similar and Related Quantitative Assessments 3.2.6
